job_title: Prospect Research Analyst in Allentown, PA
pros: Good people. Nice campus. Good food on location.
cons: Raises and cost of living adjustments are rare. Benefits were cut during covid and haven't yet been brought back to pre-pandemic levels.

pros: They look out for everyone.
cons: There are a lot of hours of work, including nights and weekends.

pros: A wonderful sense of community

pros: conscientious students and helpful support
cons: I don't have any to report

pros: It was a full-time job.

review_title: Help people pass their classes if they are struggling.
pros: I met new people and I was able to help students succeed.

pros: Rewarding work environment, that is inspiring.
cons: None, great work environment, a career long insitution.

pros: Working on a college campus is so rewarding in so many ways.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

pros: Disability services for students are first-rate, and faculty is given useful support and advice for helping students.  There's plenty of booze at faculty events, if you're into that, but non-drinkers don't really fit in. There is a lot of funding for special programs such as the Center for Ethics and Leadership and the Humanities Forum.  Tuition exchange for children of faculty is very helpful, if you have children.  Parents with children receive various kinds of support.
cons: It is a severely dysfunctional environment.  Rules are followed or ignored at the whim of management.  People are overworked and unhappy.  Faculty is expected to be available and responsive to students 24/7.  Students are coddled and catered to by this "caring college." There have been suicides and far too many deaths of cancer and heart disease among faculty.  Those faculty members with an "in" are given numerous benefits and perks, while others are shunned.  Grievances are handled poorly, and the rights of individuals are ignored.  There is lip-service to diversity, but true diversity is discouraged in myriad ways.  The administration hired big money lawyers to defeat a EEOC lawsuit.   Some departments are run well, and others very poorly.

pros: Muhlenberg is a small congenial liberal arts college with a focus on providing a caring attitude towards students.  Your experience working as a visitor there will largely depend upon the relationships in your department rather than with the administration.  The good news is that there are several recent cases of people who started out as visiting instructors who were invited to continue on to full-time positions.  Congeniality between faculty and administration is generally good, and good teaching is highly respected.
cons: As a visiting instructor, it can be easy to feel like an outsider unless you make strong efforts.  People will act welcoming at first but soon get overwhelmed by their own busy schedules.  There are a number of programs specifically for incoming faculty, however.  There is a strong culture of "busyness" at the school which can make it intimidating to approach superiors for feedback.

review_title: Good but not great - not living up to its real potential.
pros: The work environment is mostly collegial and laid back, with relatively little top-down supervision or oversight. The campus is pleasant, and convenient to a variety of eating, shopping, and living opportunities.
cons:
Like many small colleges, too many administrators, faculty, and staff just go through the motions. The "strategic plan" isn't -- it's a shopping list of fundraising priorities.
Departments and other units on campus have "external reviews", 
but the reviewers often lack the time & experience to do a good job, 
which doesn't really matter since their reports are usually ignored. 
Faculty are supposed to be focused on student learning, 
but too many use ineffective techniques (lecture, insufficient student work & feedback),
and lack the time, resources, and/or motivation to stay active and current in their specialties.

pros: Muhlenberg is a great college with wonderful students and exceptionally talented professors and staff.
cons: At the departmental level, communication is a major problem.  In my department morale is quite low and there is an overwhelming feeling of competition and dissatisfaction with many areas of operation, such as evaluations, reward and recognition for outstanding work, continued education, support for research and scholastic projects, team building events and mentoring for faculty and staff.

pros: Great co-workers, room for self expression through my own department responsibilities, good variety of co-workers from other departments on campus, friendships developed out side of my direct department.
cons: No room for growth. Low wages, not a good opportunity for department transfer to improve one's job status on campus Re: higher wages, full time opportunities.

job_title: Marketing Associate; Presidential Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I was a part-time student, part-time employee, working during my senior year in exchange for free tuition. This particular position was an excellent opportunity for me financially, and gave me a full year of professional work experience before graduating and entering the workforce. I learned a ton of new skills that will certainly help me as I move forward.
cons: At the time there were a lot of complaints about, and negative qualities to upper management of the college.  Since then though, a new president has taken over and has plans to make great changes, including expanding diversity among faculty and staff.

pros: All of the staff in every department is helpful and respectful. It is a very positive environment to work in.
cons: There is not much money in each department to keep employees up to date in their fields.  This must be done on your own time with your own incentive. If you plan to leave you might find yourself out of date unless you make this a priority.

pros: Free campus housing over the summer, provides income while taking classes, the people that work at muhlenberg are generally pretty friendly and fun to work for.
cons: Not the greatest pay ever, but having free housing definitely makes it better than most. Students usually do menial tasks and don't gain very much job experience.

pros: I spent some time at Muhlenberg as a full-time visiting faculty member and have nothing but positive things to say about working for the school.  It is a beautiful campus, the students are great, and the facilities are excellent.  Working for this school proved one of the most pleasant experiences of my career thus far.
cons: I don't really have any.

review_title: Student Job — Institute of public opinion
pros: Make your own hours, simple and easy way to make money, and one of the higher paying student jobs on campus.
cons: They will hire anyone, and some workers were distracting and did less work than others.

pros: I loved working in one of the administrative offices. I gained office experience and was able to make some money in between classes.
cons: I know that it has to do with the financial aid budget, but I wish that work study wasn't capped at $900/semester

job_title: Student Information Desk Assistant in Allentown, PA
pros: The interactions with people and flexible hours. Also the ability to do homework at work after 5:00pm.
cons: None than I can think of. You may get stuck with a shift later in the day, but it'll never affect your schedule.
